title: AI in India — ISRO, Aadhaar, DigiYatra, UPI
content:
Module 1, Lesson 4: AI in India — ISRO, Aadhaar, DigiYatra, UPI

The Hook

India has built some of the world's most ambitious digital infrastructure at unprecedented scale. The "India Stack" — a set of open APIs and digital public goods — is the backbone of AI-powered services reaching over a billion people. No other country has deployed digital systems at India's scale, speed, and cost-efficiency.

Understanding how India's large-scale AI deployments work is essential for any AI practitioner who wants to build for Bharat. These systems are not just technically impressive — they represent a model for how developing nations can leapfrog traditional technology phases using AI.

The Concept

1. ISRO: AI in Space Technology

The Indian Space Research Organisation uses AI in satellite image analysis (identifying agricultural patterns, urban growth, flood mapping), autonomous fault detection in spacecraft systems, and trajectory optimisation. Chandrayaan-3's soft landing used AI-based navigation algorithms. ISRO processes terabytes of remote sensing data daily using ML pipelines.

2. Aadhaar: Biometric AI at Billion Scale

Aadhaar's biometric authentication system is the world's largest biometric database — over 1.3 billion people. AI powers fingerprint and iris matching at sub-second speed with 99.9% accuracy. The system handles over 60 million authentications per day, enabling banking (Jan Dhan), subsidies (DBT), and SIM verification.

3. DigiYatra: AI at Indian Airports

DigiYatra enables paperless airport entry using facial recognition AI. Passengers register once; thereafter, face recognition replaces boarding passes. The system is deployed at 24+ Indian airports. The AI model maps facial geometry and matches against the DGCA database in under 3 seconds.

4. UPI: AI-Powered Payments Ecosystem

India's Unified Payments Interface processed over 10 billion transactions per month in 2024. AI enables real-time fraud detection at NPCI, intelligent dispute resolution, and merchant analytics. The RBI's AI-based regulatory sandbox allows fintech companies to test AI-powered financial products safely.

5. NITI Aayog and India AI Mission

NITI Aayog's National Strategy for AI identified healthcare, agriculture, education, smart cities, and mobility as priority sectors. The India AI Mission (2024, ₹10,372 crore) funds GPU compute infrastructure, AI startups, and research centres. IndiaAI.gov.in is the central hub for AI governance and datasets.

The Illustration

India's AI story is unique: billion-scale deployment, government-led digital infrastructure, and a thriving private sector. ISRO, Aadhaar, DigiYatra, and UPI demonstrate that India is not just an AI consumer but a global innovator. As an AI practitioner in India, you are building on the strongest digital foundation in the developing world.
